24:I[78891,["529","static/chunks/529-b3a318fab494e03f.js","244","static/chunks/244-f8e89f92ed6eb924.js","839","static/chunks/839-b514104c7e948606.js","165","static/chunks/165-ae3b45f0d86ef78d.js","184","static/chunks/app/dashboard/roots/%5Broot%5D/page-e0a9e2c37c8cb20d.js"],"CardTitle"]
25:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything26:T4dc,You who believe, when you contract a debt for a stated term, put it down in writing: have a scribe write it down justly between you. No scribe should refuse to write: let him write as God has taught him, let the debtor dictate, and let him fear God, his Lord, and not diminish &#91;the debt&#93; at all. If the debtor is feeble-minded, weak, or unable to dictate, then let his guardian dictate justly. Call in two men as witnesses. If two men are not there, then call one man and two women out of those you approve as witnesses, so that if one of the two women should forget the other can remind her. Let the witnesses not refuse when they are summoned. Do not disdain to write the debt down, be it small or large, along with the time it falls due: this way is more equitable in God&rsquo;s eyes, more reliable as testimony, and more likely to prevent doubts arising between you. But if the merchandise is there and you hand it over, there is no blame on you if you do not write it down. Have witnesses present whenever you trade with one another, and let no harm be done to either scribe or witness, for if you did cause them harm, it would be a crime on your part. Be mindful of God, and He will teach you: He has full knowledge of everything27:Tb6a,<entryFree id="n23440" key="شَآءَهُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">شَآءَهُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (Msb,) [originally <foreign lang="ar">شَيِئَهُ</foreign>,] like <foreign lang="ar">خَافَهُ</foreign>, [which is originally <foreign lang="ar">خَوِفَهُ</foreign>,] (MF,) first. pers. <foreign lang="ar">شِئْتُهُ</foreign>, (S, K,) aor. <foreign lang="ar">يَشَاؤُهُ</foreign>, (Msb,) [and by poetic license <foreign lang="ar">يَشَاهُ</foreign>, without <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign>,] first pers. <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاؤُهُ</foreign>, (S. K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">شَىْءٌ</foreign> (Msb, K) and <foreign lang="ar">مَشِيْئَةٌ</foreign>, (S, * K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and <foreign lang="ar">مَشَآءَةٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مَشَائِيَةٌ</foreign>, (K,) [or these two also are simple substs.,] <hi rend="ital">He,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">I, willed, wished,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">desired, it;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">أَرَادَهُ</foreign> (Msb) and <foreign lang="ar">أَرَدْتُهُ</foreign>: (S, * K:) most of the scholastic theologians make no difference between <foreign lang="ar">المَشِيْئَةُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">الإِرَادَةُ</foreign>, though they are [said to be] originally different; for the former, in the proper language, signifies <hi rend="ital">the causing to be</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exist,</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">الإِيجَادُ</foreign>; and the latter, <hi rend="ital">the willing, wishing,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">desiring;</hi> syn. <foreign lang="ar">الطَّلَبُ</foreign>. (TA.) A Jew objected, to the Prophet, his people's saying <foreign lang="ar">مَا شَآءَ ٱللّٰهُ وَشِئْتُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">What God hath willed and I have willed</hi>], as implying the association of another being with God: therefore the Prophet ordered them to say <foreign lang="ar">مَا شَآءَ ٱللّٰهُ ثُمَّ شِئْتُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">What God hath willed, then I have willed</hi>]. (TA.) [<foreign lang="ar">مَا شَآءَ ٱللّٰهُ</foreign> as signifying <hi rend="ital">What hath God willed!</hi> is used to express admiration. And as signifying <hi rend="ital">What God willed</hi> it is a phrase often used to denote a vague, generally a great or considerable, but sometimes <pb n="1626"/> a small, number or quantity or time: See De Sacy's Relation de l'Égypte par Abdallatif, pp. 246 and 394 &amp;c.]       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  See also 1 in art. <foreign lang="ar">شوأ</foreign>    
               </entryFree>28:T432b,<entryFree id="n23444" key="شَىْءٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">شَىْءٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">A thing; anything; something; somewhat;</hi>] a word of well-known meaning: (K:) [sometimes, in poetry, written and pronounced <foreign lang="ar">شَىٌّ</foreign>: see an ex. in a verse cited voce <foreign lang="ar">صُؤَابَةٌ</foreign>: see also the last sentence but one of this paragraph:] <foreign lang="ar">الشَّىْءُ</foreign> properly signifies <hi rend="ital">what may be known, and that whereof a thing may be predicated:</hi> (Mgh, KT:) accord. to Sb, it denotes existence, and is a name for <hi rend="ital">anything that has been made to have being, whether an accident,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">attribute, or a substance, and such that it may be known, and that a thing may be predicated thereof:</hi> (KT:) MF says that it is app. an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., meaning <hi rend="ital">what is willed, and meant,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">intended,</hi> [in which sense   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n23444-1" target="مَشِيْئَةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n23449"/></foreign> (pl. <foreign lang="ar">مَشِيْآتٌ</foreign>) is often used,] <hi rend="ital">without restriction to its actuality or possibility of being,</hi> so that it applies to <hi rend="ital">that which necessarily is,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">that which may be,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">that which cannot be;</hi> accord. to the opinion adopted by the author of the Ksh: [or, as an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., it may be expl., agreeably with what is said to be the proper meaning of the verb, as signifying <hi rend="ital">what is caused to be</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exist;</hi> accordingly,] Er-Rághib says that it denotes <hi rend="ital">whatever is caused to be</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exist, whether sensibly, as material substances,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ideally, as sayings;</hi> and Bd and others expressly assert that it signifies peculiarly <hi rend="ital">what is caused to be</hi> or <hi rend="ital">exist;</hi> but Sb says that it is the most general of general terms; and some of the scholastic theologians apply it to <hi rend="ital">what is non-existent;</hi> such, however, are overcome in their argument by its not being found to have been thus used by the Arabs, and by such passages as <foreign lang="ar">كُلُّ شَىْءٍ هَالِكٌ إِلَّا وَجْهَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Everything is subject to perish except Himself</hi> (Kur xxviii. last verse)] and <foreign lang="ar">وَإِنْ مِنْ شَىْءٍ إِلَّا يُسَبِّحُ بِحَمْدِهِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">And there is not anything but it glorifies Him with praising</hi> (Kur xvii. 46)], for what is nonexistent cannot be described as perishing nor imagined to glorify God: (TA:) the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">أَشْيَآءُ</foreign>, (S, Msb, K, &amp;c.,) imperfectly decl., (Msb, TA,) or rather this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) respecting the formation of which there is much difference of opinion [as will be shown hereafter], (Msb, TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">أَشْيَاوَاتٌ</foreign>, (S, K,) a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَشْيَآءٌ</foreign>], (MF, TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوَاتٌ</foreign>, [a contraction of that next preceding,] (K,) and <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوَى</foreign>, (S, K,) with fet-h to the <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign>, (MF, TA,) and it is also mentioned as with kesr, (TA,) [and is written in both of my copies of the S <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوَى</foreign>, though if with kesr it should be either <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوٍ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوِىُّ</foreign>, but <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوَى</foreign> only is meant by J, as is shown by what here follows,] originally <foreign lang="ar">أَشَايِىُّ</foreign>, with three <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> s, not <foreign lang="ar">أَشَائِىُّ</foreign> as J says, [or rather as the word is written in copies of the S, for J may have held it to be <foreign lang="ar">أَشَائِىُّ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">أَشَايِىْءُ</foreign>, as he says that the <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign> was changed into <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> thus occasioning the combination of three <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign>s, so that he held its secondary form to be <foreign lang="ar">أَشَايِىُّ</foreign>, as will presently be shown,] because the first <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> is radical, not augmentative, (IB, K,) the medial <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> of the three being suppressed, and the final one changed into <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign> [though written <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign>], and the initial one changed into <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign>, (S,) and another form of pl. is <foreign lang="ar">أَشَايَا</foreign>, (S, Msb, K,) with the <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> preserved, not changed into <foreign lang="ar">و</foreign> [as it is in <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوَى</foreign>], (TA,) [likewise] a pl. of <foreign lang="ar">أَشْيَآءُ</foreign>, (Msb,) and <foreign lang="ar">أَشَيَايَا</foreign> also is mentioned, (K,) as formed [from <foreign lang="ar">أَشْيَآءُ</foreign>] by the change of <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign> into <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> and adding <foreign lang="ar">ا</foreign>, (TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوِهُ</foreign>, which is strange, (Lh, K,) as there is no <foreign lang="ar">ه</foreign> in <foreign lang="ar">أَشَيَآءُ</foreign>, (Lh,) or in <foreign lang="ar">شَىْءٌ</foreign>: (K:) with respect to the first of these forms, [the quasi-pl. n.] <foreign lang="ar">أَشَيَآءُ</foreign>, the most probable opinion is that of Kh: (Msb, TA:) accord. to him, (S, Msb, K,) it is originally of the measure <foreign lang="ar">فَعْلَآءُ</foreign>, (S, K, *) in lieu of <foreign lang="ar">أَفْعَالٌ</foreign>, (K,) and therefore imperfectly decl., (S,) [i. e.] it is originally <foreign lang="ar">شَيْئَآءُ</foreign>, (Msb,) and the two hemzehs combined in the latter portion being found difficult of pronunciation, the former of them is transposed to the beginning of the word, so that it becomes of the measure <foreign lang="ar">لَفْعَآءُ</foreign>, (S, Msb,) as is shown by its having for its pls. <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوَى</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَشَايَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَشْيَاوَاتٌ</foreign>: (S:) accord. to Akh, it is [originally] of the measure <foreign lang="ar">أَفْعِلَآءُ</foreign>; (S, K;) but if it were thus a broken pl., [not a quasi-pl. n.,] its dim. would not be   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n23444-2" target="أُشْيَّآءُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, as it is, but <foreign lang="ar">شُيَيْآتٌ</foreign>: (S:) accord. to Ks, it is of the measure <foreign lang="ar">أَفْعَالٌ</foreign>, and made imperfectly decl. because of frequency of usage, being likened to <foreign lang="ar">فَعْلَآءُ</foreign>; but were it so, <foreign lang="ar">أَبْنَآء</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">أَسْمَآء</foreign> would be imperfectly decl.: (S, K:) accord. to Fr, <foreign lang="ar">شَىْءٌ</foreign> is originally <foreign lang="ar">شَيِّئٌ</foreign>, and therefore has a pl. of the measure <foreign lang="ar">أَفْعِلَآءُ</foreign>, afterwards contracted to <foreign lang="ar">فَعْلَآءُ</foreign>; but were it so, it would not have for its pl. <foreign lang="ar">أَشَاوَى</foreign>. (S. [Much more respecting this pl. is added in the TA, but it is comparatively unprofitable.]) The dim. of <foreign lang="ar">شَىْءٌ</foreign> is   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n23444-3" target="شُيَىْءٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n23446"/></foreign> and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n23444-4" target="شِيَىْءٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (S, K, TA, but only the former in some copies of the K, the word being written in other copies <foreign lang="ar">شُِيَىْءٌ</foreign>;) not   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n23444-5" target="شُوَىٌّ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n23444-6" target="شُوَىْءٌ" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>; (the former accord. to my two copies of the S and accord. to the copies of the K followed in the TA, in which it is said to be with teshdeed to the <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign>, and the latter accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K;) or this is a dial. var. of weak authority, (K,) used by post-classical poets in their verses. (MF, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  When a man says to thee, “ What dost thou desire? ” thou answerest, <foreign lang="ar">لَا شَيْئًا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Nothing</hi>]: and when he says, “ Why didst thou that? ” thou answerest, <foreign lang="ar">لِلَا شَىْءٍ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">For nothing</hi>]: and when he says, “ What is thine affair? ” thou answerest, <foreign lang="ar">لَا شَىْءٌ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Nothing</hi>]: it is with tenween in every one of these cases. (As, AHát, TA.) [When one says <foreign lang="ar">لَا شَىْءَ</foreign>, he means thereby <hi rend="ital">There is nothing.</hi>]          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">لَيْسَ بِشَىْءٍ</foreign> means [<hi rend="ital">It is nought, of no account</hi> or <hi rend="ital">weight; it is not worthy of notice,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">not worth anything;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">it is not a good thing;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">it is not a thing to be regarded.</hi> (W p. 27.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  [<foreign lang="ar">لَيْسَ مِنَ الأَمْرِ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فِى شَىْءٍ</foreign> is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning <hi rend="ital">He has no concern with the affair;</hi> see two exs. in the first paragraph of art. <foreign lang="ar">حوص</foreign>.          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">فِيهِ شَىْءٍِ مِنَ الطُّولِ</foreign> occurs in the TA voce <foreign lang="ar">حُسْبَانَةٌ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">In it is somewhat,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">some degree, of length;</hi> i. e. <hi rend="ital">it is somewhat long;</hi> and is used in the present day in this sense.]          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  In the phrase <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ أَحْسَنُ مِنْكَ شَيْئًا</foreign>, the last word is for <foreign lang="ar">بِشَىْءٍ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">He is better than thou in something;</hi> meaning <hi rend="ital">he is somewhat better than thou</hi>]. (IJ, L.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَغْفَلَهُ عَنْكَ شَيْئًا</foreign> is a phrase of the Arabs [app. lit. signifying <hi rend="ital">How unmindful of thee is he as to anything!</hi>] mentioned by Sb as meaning <foreign lang="ar">دَعِ الشَّكَّ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَنْكَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Dismiss doubt from thee</hi> (<hi rend="ital">respecting him as to anything</hi>)]: IJ says that <foreign lang="ar">شيئا</foreign> is here put in the accus. case as an inf. n., as though the saying were <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَغْفَلَهُ عَنْكَ غُفُولًا</foreign>, because the verb of wonder does not require to be corroborated by the inf. n. [proper to it]: (L, TA:) [or it is a specificative:] IF says that it is a phrase of dubious meaning; and that the most probable explanation of it is this; that <foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign> is here lit. interrogative, but in meaning denotative of wonder; and that <foreign lang="ar">شيئا</foreign> is governed in the accus. case by some other word, or phrase, as though the saying were <hi rend="ital">dismiss a thing by which he is not occupied in mind, and dismiss doubt as to his being occupied in mind by it.</hi> (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  [<foreign lang="ar">شَيْئًا فَشَيْئًا</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">Thing by thing, part by part, bit by bit, piecemeal, inch by inch, drop by drop, little and little in succession, by little and little, by degrees</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gradually.</hi>]          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">أَىُّ شَىْءٍ</foreign> [meaning <hi rend="ital">What thing?</hi>] is, by the alleviation of the <foreign lang="ar">ى</foreign> [in <foreign lang="ar">اىّ</foreign>] and the suppression of the <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign> [in <foreign lang="ar">شىء</foreign>], made into one word, <foreign lang="ar">أَيْشَىْ</foreign>: so says El-Fárábee: (Msb:) or, [as is commonly the case in the present day,] by reason of frequency of usage, it is contracted into <foreign lang="ar">أَيْشَ</foreign>. (TA in art. <foreign lang="ar">جرم</foreign>, as on the authority of Ks.)          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">شَىْءٌ</foreign> in the Kur lx. 11 may mean <hi rend="ital">Any one</hi> (Bd, Jel) or <hi rend="ital">more.</hi> (Jel.)          <sense type="b" n="11">-b11-</sense>  [It is also applied to <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  The <hi rend="ital">penis</hi> of a man; as in the explanation of a phrase mentioned voce <foreign lang="ar">ذَنَبٌ</foreign>; like as its syn. <foreign lang="ar">هَنٌ</foreign> is to the same and (more commonly) to the “ vulva ” of a woman.]          <sense type="b" n="12">-b12-</sense>  In algebra, it signifies [<hi rend="ital">A square root;</hi>] <hi rend="ital">a number that is multiplied into itself;</hi> which in arithmetic [and in algebra also] is called <foreign lang="ar">جذر</foreign> [i. e. <foreign lang="ar">جَذْرٌ</foreign>]; and in geometry, <foreign lang="ar">ضلع</foreign> [i. e. <foreign lang="ar">ضِلْعٌ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">ضِلَعٌ</foreign>]; (“ Dict. of the Techn. Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans, ” p. 202;) <hi rend="ital">an unknown number that is multiplied into itself.</hi> 
                  <pb n="1627"/> (Idem, p. 730.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  It is also said, on the authority of Lth, to signify <hi rend="ital">Water:</hi> and he cites as an ex., <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">تَرَى رَكْبَهُ بِالشَّىْءِ فِى وَسْطِ قَفْرَةٍ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [<hi rend="ital">Thou seest,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wilt see, his company of riders at the water in the midst of a desert</hi>]: but AM says, I know not <foreign lang="ar">الشىء</foreign> in the sense of “ water, ” nor know I what it is. (TA.)       <sense type="A" n="3">-A3-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">يَا شَىْءَ</foreign> is an expression of regret, (El-Ahmar, Ks, TA,) or of wonder, (K, TA,) [or of both,] meaning [<hi rend="ital">Oh!</hi> or] <hi rend="ital">O my wonder!</hi> (Ks, Lh, TA.) One says, <foreign lang="ar">يَا شَىْءَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَا لِى</foreign>, (El-Ahmar, Ks, Lh, K,) and <foreign lang="ar">يَا شَىَّ مَا لِى</foreign>, i. e. with and without <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign>, (Ks, TA,) and <foreign lang="ar">يَا هَىْءَ مَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">لِى</foreign>, (Lh, K,) <foreign lang="ar">يا هَىَّ ما لى</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">يَا فَىَّ ما لى</foreign>, (El-Ahmar, Ks, TA,) neither of these two with <foreign lang="ar">ء</foreign>, (Ks, TA,) [meaning <hi rend="ital">Oh!</hi> or <hi rend="ital">O my wonder! What has happened to me?</hi>] in all of these, (Ks, TA,) <foreign lang="ar">ما</foreign> being in the place of a noun in the nom. case. (Ks, Lh, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Some also say, <foreign lang="ar">يَا شَىْءَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">يَا هَىَّ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">يَا فَىَّ</foreign>, and some add <foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign>, saying, <foreign lang="ar">يَا شَىْءَ مَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">يَا هَىَّ مَا</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">يَا فَىَّ مَا</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">How good,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">beautiful, is this!</hi> (Ks, TA.) full poem ",["$","svg",null,{"stroke":"currentColor","fill":"currentColor","strokeWidth":"0","viewBox":"0 0 512
